title: 21062 Iasky
text:
21062 Iasky, provisional designation , is a dark background <a href="asteroid">asteroid</a> from the outer regions of the <a href="asteroid%20belt">asteroid belt</a>, approximately in diameter. It was discovered on 13 May 1991, by American astronomers <a href="Carolyn%20Shoemaker">Carolyn</a> and <a href="Eugene%20Shoemaker">Eugene Shoemaker</a> at the <a href="Palomar%20Observatory">Palomar Observatory</a> in California. It was named for Australian geophysicist <a href="Robert%20Iasky">Robert Iasky</a>.
Orbit and classification.
"Iasky" is a non-<a href="Asteroid%20family">family</a> asteroid from the main belt's <a href="Background%20asteroid">background population</a>. It orbits the Sun in the <a href="Kirkwood%20gap">outer</a> asteroid belt at a distance of 2.9–3.1 <a href="Astronomical%20unit">AU</a> once every 5 years and 4 months (1,940 days; <a href="semi-major%20axis">semi-major axis</a> of 3.04 AU). Its orbit has an <a href="orbital%20eccentricity">eccentricity</a> of 0.03 and an <a href="orbital%20inclination">inclination</a> of 24<a href="Degree%20%28angle%29">°</a> with respect to the <a href="ecliptic">ecliptic</a>. The body's <a href="observation%20arc">observation arc</a> begins in November 1982, with its first observations taken by the <a href="Siding%20Spring%20Observatory">Siding Spring Observatory</a> and published with the <a href="Digitized%20Sky%20Survey">Digitized Sky Survey</a> later on.
Naming.
This <a href="minor%20planet">minor planet</a> was named after Australian geophysicist <a href="Robert%20Iasky">Robert Iasky</a> (born 1956), who discovered the 120-kilometer-sized <a href="Woodleigh%20crater">Woodleigh crater</a> in the <a href="Carnarvon%20Basin">Carnarvon Basin</a> of Western Australia while working with the <a href="Geological%20Survey%20of%20Western%20Australia">Geological Survey of Western Australia</a>. The official was published by the <a href="Minor%20Planet%20Center">Minor Planet Center</a> on 1 May 2003 ().
Physical characteristics.
According to the survey carried out by the <a href="NEOWISE">NEOWISE</a> mission of NASA's <a href="Wide-field%20Infrared%20Survey%20Explorer">Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</a>, "Iasky" measures 19.034 kilometers in diameter and its surface has an <a href="astronomical%20albedo">albedo</a> of 0.063, which is typical for a carbonaceous <a href="C-type%20asteroid">C-type asteroid</a>. As of 2018, no rotational <a href="lightcurve">lightcurve</a> of "Iasky" has been obtained from <a href="Photometry%20%28astronomy%29">photometric</a> observations. The body's <a href="rotation%20period">rotation period</a>, <a href="Poles%20of%20astronomical%20bodies">pole</a> and shape remain unknown.
In literature.
In his 1994 book <a href="Pale%20Blue%20Dot%20%28book%29">"Pale Blue Dot"</a>, Astronomer <a href="Carl%20Sagan">Carl Sagan</a> speculated on the nature of ("Iasky"):
Asteroid 1991JW has an orbit very much like the Earth's and is even easier to get to than <a href="4660%26amp%3Bnbsp%3BNereus">4660 Nereus</a>. But its orbit seems "too" similar to the Earth's for it to be a natural object. Perhaps it's some lost upper stage of the "<a href="Saturn%20V">Saturn V</a> Apollo" moon rocket".
This is however quite mysterious, as the orbit of 20162 Iasky is located in the outer asteroid belt.
